utterances: Thank you.
Bye-bye.

And when you're hearing stories like that, Ken - and those are not the only places where there hitches or not enough envelopes or there were other problems, (unintelligible) but most of them caused by the phenomenal turnout.
From the moment the Iowans participated in the caucuses on January 3rd I guess it was - it's been so long ago although it's only like a month ago.
But the turnout on both parties, but especially on the Democratic side has been record breaking.
It's just phenomenal.
And it's so disappointing to hear that state election officials in subsequent states since Iowa, New Hampshire did not prepare for this onslaught of voters.

You know, you hear the story from Wichita is heartwarming in the sense that enthusiasm was there, but the fact that many votes did not count, many people could not stay long enough until provisional ballots were - they came up with it, that's disappointing.
Let's get Craig(ph) on the line.
Craig calling us from Haley in Idaho.
Yeah.

We're - we've experienced sort of the same things that I'm hearing on the show where, you know, everybody was inundated for our caucus, it's only about 1200 people made it in before basically it would have been a fire hazard to have any more people in our local auditorium.
There was where the traffic was backed up through town and they're trying to get voting slips out to the people waiting outside.
It started snowing.
It was cold.
But it was amazing to see the range of ages.
People commenting on, you know, back in Kennedy - referring to Kennedy and - Robert Kennedy, also high school seniors who just turned 18 signing up to become delegates for the June 12th state…
Convention I think it is, yes.
…convention that's going to happen here in Idaho.
And just the fact that out of the 1200 people in the auditorium that were voting, only about 160 went for Hillary Clinton, and that didn't even give her enough percentage to have a single delegate.
So all of us here in Blaine County looks like will go to Obama, which was pretty much heartfelt in the auditorium that night, last night.
It was amazing.
Well, thanks very much for that report.
Ken?
You know, it was amazing that Don Gonyea had a piece on NPR over the weekend.
He was with the Obama campaign.
And I guess - I think it was Boise, and there were thousands and thousands and thousands.
And you think of, you know, Idaho is - you don't think of it as a Democratic stronghold, shall we say.
Joanne who called earlier from Wichita said that she hopes that Kansas will be a blue state in November.
Now, both Idaho and Kansas have not gone Democratic since Lyndon Johnson in 1964.
But again, there was so much enthusiasm out there on both sides.
But again, we're hearing it more and more from the Democrats, you wonder if there - it doesn't change in November.
Craig, thanks very much for the call.
Thank you.
We're talking with NPR political editor Ken Rudin.
And we want to hear from you as well.
Republicans and independents: 800-344-3893.
Democrats and independents: 800-344-3864.
E-mail us, talk@npr.org.
When we come back we'll be talking with pollster Andy Kohut of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press.
Stay with us.
It's a Special Report from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is an NPR News Special.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
And all 24 states held primary contests or presidential nominating contests yesterday and the final tallies are just one part of the story.
Thanks to exit poll data, we're learning more about exactly who came out to vote or caucused on Super Tuesday and what drove their decisions.
We're also getting a better idea of just how many turned out.
And Luis, tell us what happened in California last night where the Latino vote seemed to prove decisive for Senator Clinton.
If you voted, caucused, or worked the election yesterday, call us.
Describe what it looked and felt like, what other voters were saying and doing.
Again, split lines.
Republicans can reach us at 800-344-3893.
Independents can call in on either line.
And of course everyone can e-mail to the same address, talk@npr.org.
NPR political editor Ken Rudin is with us.
And joining us here in the studio is Andy Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press.
And, Andy, I know you had a late night, too, we appreciate your coming in.
Happy to do it.
And the numbers of people who voted yesterday is just phenomenal.
I have a number for you with respect to that.
It's 24 percent.
Twenty-four percent is the number of people who are satisfied with national conditions, much lower than in most national elections.
And when we get surges in voting, it's not a consequence of a spike in civic engagement, it's a consequence of Americans being unhappy with that status quo.
And that is certainly the case, and it's particularly the case among Democrats and Democratic participation.
It is, in fact, exceeding Republican participation.
Of the 25 million or so who voted yesterday, 14.7 million Democrats by an NPR count.
Total Republicans - and these are just in the states that had both Democratic and Republican primaries yesterday - 8.9 million.
Yeah.
And I'm not trying to dismiss Republican participation.
It's pretty intense in a lot of places.
It's a real contest between these three candidates.
Here's an e-mail from Kent(ph) in Oregon.
Record turnouts in many if not all the primaries occurred yesterday, was this the result of the one person not mentioned in any of the campaign speeches last night - George W.
Bush?
Even Mitt Romney in his speech last night was very specific in mentioning other Republican presidents including George Herbert Walker Bush, but no mention of George W.
How are the candidates handling the current president?
As little as possible I think is the answer on the Republican side and as much as possible on the Democratic side.
And I think a large part of the reason why there's so much energy here is because people have been discontented with President Bush's second term.
And he's a real - continues to be a real problem for the Republicans, among independent voters.
But, you know, we'll see that play out in the general.
As you looked at the exit polls from yesterday and as you've had a chance to sleep, if briefly, on the some of the figures, what's surprises you?
Well, one of the surprises was the role of Latinos in California.
They were represented - 30 percent of the Democratic electorate.
A very big number, a little bigger than I think many pollsters expected.
And they decisively went for Hillary Clinton.
Blacks went overwhelmingly for Obama.
I think the race was pretty even among whites, which is a pretty good showing for Obama, because in the past he hasn't done so well among whites.
But they certainly made the difference.
They voted according to the semi-final exit poll.
At California 66 - Latinos this is - 66 to 33 Clinton for Obama.
But in other states, I think as has been pointed out, New Mexico - we have Latino votes put pretty evenly.
In Connecticut, I think Obama in fact got a plurality of the Latino vote.
But that was really a big surprise.

But a lot of it wasn't so surprising; it was building on what we'd seen, the patterns that we'd seen - gender, race, age, ideology, social class and political independence - making a difference on the Democratic side.
And yes, there was some variation from state to state, but this really did have the character of a national primary with trends that we saw pretty much in most places.
On the Republican side, the divisions among the candidates are much sharper.
You can draw distinct ideological divisions among them.
Did that show up in the exit polls?
It did.
I mean, it showed up in every - in just about - I think in everyone except Georgia.
McCain won the vote of independents, who considered themselves independents even though they were voting sometimes in closed primaries.
He also won the vote of moderates.
And what happened in many places, Huckabee and Romney split the conservative vote.
Except in the south where Huckabee had such a large share of the white evangelical Protestant vote.
Mm-hmm.
I've heard it describes almost as a denominational split.
The Baptist voted for Mike Huckabee.
Yeah.
I mean, if you look at the white evangelical Protestant vote, it's - it was very strong for Huckabee and where it's very large in the southern states, which are largely Baptists.
So this could either be denominational or regional.
But if you get up into - look at the states in the north where the numbers are smaller, Huckabee didn't really do that well among white evangelical Protestants.
He did reasonably well, but didn't win them in many states.
And Ken Rudin, as we mentioned earlier, Mike Huckabee did pretty well yesterday and won in a lot of places nobody expected him necessarily to win.
But as he looks ahead, haven't most of the places where he can expect to do well, already voted?
Well, that's exactly right.
Obviously, the states that - his best states were always considered South Carolina, which he narrowly lost and he won Georgia and Alabama, Tennessee.
As we said, not much left in the south for him to pick and choose at - off.
The next big southern primary, of course, we have next week is Virginia, but that's less, I think, good for the kind of appeal that Huckabee is making.
Texas is March 4th, which is quasi southern - it's more western than anything.
So I think it's very possible that Mike Huckabee's best days may be behind him.
But look, he surprised us so far.
We didn't expect him to win in many of the states he did carry yesterday.
So who knows?
But I would suspect that Mike Huckabee's best days - best day may have been yesterday.
Mm-hmm.
I would just prefer it to be the popular vote.
I feel that - I realized that we may still have lost, but I would feel that in the big picture if you added up all the votes on both sides, it would be more even.
I just feel that we need to reflect on a national basis what people want.
And if we go state by state, I feel that it's more divisive.
It divides us into us or them rather than looking at the big picture.
Let me give you some numbers from the Pew database.
Among Republicans in Virginia, 43 percent of them are white evangelical Protestants, which is higher than the average 35 percent.
Maryland is about 29 percent, which is to say lower.
So Virginia might not be bad for Huckabee.
But you're right.
When you go on further - when you go further, it's not going to look good for Huckabee, because the numbers are going to get smaller.
Let's say, Wisconsin 28 percent and so on.
But here's one of other thing I was (unintelligible) to.
If Mitt Romney finds that his 35, $40 million investment so far has not panned out, that he feels that why keep doing - if I'm not going to win.
He won Utah.
He won Massachusetts.
He won some Rocky Mountain states yesterday…
You mean places where he lived.
Right.
But I don't think he lived in Montana.
Well, yeah, that will be abut.
No, but - sorry.
But I'm saying if, you know, if he decides - he says he'll on to the convention, that's what he said yesterday.
But we've heard John Edwards say he'll go on to the convention, too.
But if Mitt Romney pulls out, the demographics may not be there for Mike Huckabee.
But if Mike Huckabee becomes the conservative alternative to John McCain, he could do better than a lot of us think.
Yes.
Because McCain, except in a few places, really didn't win a large majority among regular Republicans, and in most places didn't win a plurality among conservative voters.
So yes, Huckabee or Romney could become the non-McCain if the other wasn't there.
Let's get another caller on the line and go to Bemidji, Minnesota.
And Patricia(ph) is on the air.
Yes.
Thank you for taking my call.
Sure.
